--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> >
> >In addition I often wonder if we shouldn't just replace the old 
style
> >neuron with sigmoid activation fn with nodes that apply one of a 
fixed
> >set of functions. A sort of  EP-NEAT fusion, this is basically 
what I
> >was describing a while ago in the discussion about good benchmark
> >functions. Does anyone have a good argument for/against this? I 
suppose
> >aligning the input/output value ranges of different functions is 
one
> >problem, but that could be solved by with a bit of normalisation 
I suspect.
> 
> This is also an idea on my todo-list and will fit very easily into 
this 
> framework...
> 

I also think this is a good idea, and on my todo list as well.  
There is no reason sigmoids should be the only activation function, 
and the more I have thought about this, the more convinced I have 
become that it would help, though the question of what those other 
functions should be is important.  Have you guys look at Mattias 
Fagerlund's DelphiNEAT function approximation demo?  I believe he 
used several non-sigmoid activation functions in that version of 
NEAT, and as can be seen, it approximates some pretty diverse 
functions quite well.

ken

> >
> >
> >Colin
> 
> Ian
> 
> In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
